titleInfo.title: SPARROW Surface Water-Quality Modeling Nutrients in Watersheds of the Coterminous United States

name.namePart: Smith, R.A., G.E. Schwarz, and R.B. Alexander

Citation_mods.note: Smith, R.A. et al. 1997. SPARROW Surface Water-Quality Modeling Nutrients in Watersheds of the Coterminous United States. Regional interpretation of water-quality monitoring data, Water Resources Research, v. 33, no. 12, pp.2781-2798

titleInfo.title: SPARROW MODELING - Enhancing Understanding of the Nation's Water Quality

name.namePart: Preston, S.D., Alexander, R.B., Woodside, M.D., and Hamilton, P.A.

Citation_mods.note: Preston, S.D., Alexander, R.B., Woodside, M.D., and Hamilton, P.A., 2009, SPARROW MODELING-Enhancing Understanding of the Nation's Water Quality: U.S. Geological Survey Fact Sheet 2009-3019, 6 p.

Term.p: The US is divided into 8 major river basins: New England and Mid-Atlantic; South Atlantic-Gulf and Tennessee; Great Lakes, Ohio, Upper Mississippi and Souris-Red-Rainy; Missouri; Lower Mississippi, Arkansas-White-Red and Texas-Gulf; Rio Grande, Colorado and Great Basin; Pacific Northwest; and California.

The Data Series specifies what data is drawn on the map. The most common model output is the Total Instream Flux, which is the average amount of the constituent you would expect to find in a stream, as predicted by the model.

ul.li:
Total Instream Flux
The average daily load of the constituent leaving each stream reach, as predicted by the model. This is also called the measurable flux since this is the hypothetical value you could measure in the stream, if there was a way to measure daily average.

Incremental Flux
The average daily load of the constituent added at each stream reach. Or, the amount of load that each reach is responsible for contributing to the river system. The presented value is not 'decayed' by travel down the reach.

Incremental Yield
The Incremental Flux divided by the drainage area of the reach.

Concentration
The Total Instream Flux divided by the average daily flow of the reach.

Source Value
The source value is the amount of a particular source added in the reaches drainage area - you must choose a source when you choose this data series. If you have created adjustments as part of a 'what if' scenario, the adjusted source values are presented.

Delivery Fraction
The fraction of the load leaving a reach that arrives at the downstream end of a selected target reach. You must choose a target reach if you select this series.

Incremental Delivered Flux
Not currently supported

Total Delivered Flux
Not currently supported

Incremental Delivered Yield
Not currently supported

Total Standard Err Estimate
An estimate of error, based on the model, of the Total Instream Flux. This is only an estimate and should not be used for any purpose. For actual error values, contact the hydrologist for the model.

Incremental Standard Err Estimate
An estimate of error, based on the model, of the Incremental Flux. This is only an estimate and should not be used for any purpose. For actual error values, contact the hydrologist for the model.

CommonTerms.Term: Takes into account constituent sources upstream and degradation to describe the annual load of the constituent being transported by national surface waters. Units are typically kilograms/year.
Takes into account only sources of the constituent within the surrounding catchment to show local generation of the constituent independent of the upstream load. Units are typically kilograms/year.

Takes into account only sources of the constituent within the surrounding catchment to show the local generation of the constituent normalized for catchment area. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Total load divided by the long-term average flow of the stream reach. Units are typically kilograms/cubic feet.
Displays the location and frequency of constituent sources. Units are typically kilograms/year.
Displays the fraction of incremental load that is delivered to a target reach of interest.
Displays the incremental flux generated by a catchment that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Displays the total flux including sources upstream and within the catchment that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Displays the incremental yield that is delivered to a target reach of interest. Units are typically kilograms/square kilometer-year.
Each model has different sources that were determined by statistically significant by the modeler. Choose a constituent source from the list to present data only from that source.

For the selected Data Series, the result generated by your adjusted values can be compared to the result of the unadjusted model. Two options are available:
Absolute change from nominal subtracts the nominal (unadjusted) model result from the adjusted model result.
% change from nominal presents the percent increase of the adjusted model result over the nominal model result. That is:
100 X (adjusted - nominal) / nominal
Any increase from a nominal value of zero is considered a 100% change. Any decrease from a nominal value of zero is considered a -100% change.
The nominal SPARROW DSS model condition is based on source values and streamflow of the model base year.

The bins determine how values grouped and displayed on the map. For instance, you might create bins 0-10 and 10-100 and have the values in the 0-10 bin colored grey and values in the 10-100 bin colored as red. Two auto-generation options are available:
Equal Count attempts to construct bins such that an equal number of data values fall within each bin. Because the values are sometimes clustered, it is often not possible to generate bins with an even distribution of values into each bin.
Equal Range construct bins such that each bin has an equal size or range.
You must define bins before a map is generated.
Controls basic features of how the map is rendered. Click the headings of the subsections for more information on each feature.
Stream segments that extend between confluence with other streams.
A watershed that drains to a single stream.
Calculates the average, maximum, minimum, or sum of the model output when the map displays over HUC.

Selecting 'Reaches' will draw individual reach lines on the map. Selecting 'Catchments' will draw the filled polygons of each catchment. In both cases, the color used to render the reach or catchment is based on the binning selection under the 'What to map' section.
